Method Summary
static long ATDX_CONNTYPE(int dev)
          Returns the connection for the call on the given device after @link dx#dial(int, String, DX_CAP, int) when using call analysis.
static long ATDX_CPTERM(int dev)
          Determins call termination conditions when using call analysis.
static long ATDX_HOOKST(int dev)
          Returns the hookstate of the specified handle.
static long ATDX_LONGLOW(int dev)
          Returns duration of long low from call analysis.
static long ATDX_SHORTLOW(int dev)
          Returns duration of the shorter silence from call analysis.
static long ATDX_SIZEHI(int dev)
          Returns duration of initial detected signal from call analysis.
static long ATDX_TERMMSK(int dev)
          Returns reason for temination of the last IO call.
static long ATDX_TRCOUNT(int dev)
          Returns the number of bytes transfered in the last play or record on the given channel.
static TN_GEN bldtngen(int freq1, int freq2, int ampl1, int ampl2, int duration)
          Instead of specifing a pointer to a TN_GEN structure (Dialogic API), that argument is omitted and a net.threebit.jvr.TN_GEN object is returned instead.

getdig

public static java.lang.String getdig(int dev,
                                      DV_TPT[] tpt,
                                      DV_DIGIT digit,
                                      int mode)
                               throws JVRException
Gets digits on the device with the given handle.

Dialogic API Reference for this function: (win32,linux)

In addition to the provided digit parameter, when called in synchronous mode, getdig will return a String containing the digits that were collected (if any). Otherwise null is returned. In asynchronous mode, null is always returned and the collected digits will be available in the given digit buffer.

Parameters:
dev - handle to device on which to perform action device to use
tpt - termination parameters
digit - digits, when asynchronous
mode - [EV_SYNC|EV_ASYNC]
Returns:
digits, when synchrous
Throws:
JVRException - on error

playvox

public static int playvox(int dev,
                          java.lang.String filename,
                          DV_TPT[] tpt,
                          DX_XPB xpb,
                          int mode)
                   throws JVRException
Plays a given VOX file using the device of the given handle with the given termination conditions.

Dialogic API Reference for this function: (win32,linux)

VOX Links:

  • vox/devox: wav <-> vox
  • Adobe Audition: ex-cool edit, now even more expense!
  • JavaSound vox tip (note: no javasound vox processor exists, perhaps you want to write one?)

Example:

     DV_TPT[] tpts=tpt.newArray(1);
 tpts[0].tp_type=dx.IO_EOT; // end on tone
 tpts[0].tp_termno=dx.DX_MAXDTMF; // max # of dtmf inputs
 tpts[0].tp_length=1; // term on press of 1
 tpts[0].tp_flags=dx.TF_MAXDTMF; //  terminate with max # of digits
 dx.playvox(id, file.getAbsolutePath(), tpts, null, dx.EV_SYNC);

Parameters:
dev - handle to device on which to perform action device handle
filename - vox to play
tpt - Termination Parameter Table
xpb - IO Transfer Block (can be null)
mode - play mode. Combination of [EV_SYNC|EV_ASYNC],MD_ADPCM,MD_PCM,PM_ALAW,PM_TONE,PM_SR6,PM_SR8,PM_ADSIALERT,PM_ADSI
Returns:
nothing useful, exception on error
Throws:
JVRException - on error playing.

                          int mode)

Dialogic API Reference for this function: (win32)

filename - vox to play
tpt - Termination Parameter Table
mode - Play Mode. Must be dx.EV_SYNC or dx.PM_TONE|dx.EV_SYNC if you want a 200ms audible tone to play before the WAV file.
Returns:
nothing useful, exception on error
Throws:
JVRException - on error playing.

fileopen

public static int fileopen(java.lang.String filename,
                           int flags,
                           int pmode)
                    throws JVRException
dx_fileopen.

Dialogic API Reference for this function: (win32)

This function is not ordinarialy available under Linux, but since Java programs cannot call the Unix/Posix fopen() function, JVR provides this method under Linux. See "man open" for more details.

Parameters:
filename - Name of file to open.

flags - Flags that are passed to the native file open function.

On win32, bitwise or of: WIN32_O_APPEND, WIN32_O_BINARY, WIN32_O_CREAT, WIN32_O_RDONLY, WIN32_O_RDWR, WIN32_O_SEQUENTIAL, WIN32_O_TEXT, WIN32_O_TRUNC, WIN32_O_WRONLY, WIN32_S_IREAD, WIN32_S_IWRITE.

On linux, bitwise or of: LINUX_O_APPEND, LINUX_O_CREAT, LINUX_O_EXCL, LINUX_O_LARGEFILE, LINUX_O_NDELAY, LINUX_O_NOCTTY, LINUX_O_NOFOLLOW, LINUX_O_NONBLOCK, LINUX_O_SYNC, LINUX_O_TRUNC.

pmode - Mode parameter that is passed to the native file open function.

On win32, bitwise or of: WIN32_S_IREAD, WIN32_S_IWRITE.

On linux, bitwise or of: LINUX_S_IRGRP, LINUX_S_IROTH, LINUX_S_IRUSR, LINUX_S_IRWXG, LINUX_S_IRWXO, LINUX_S_IRWXU, LINUX_S_IWGRP, LINUX_S_IWOTH, LINUX_S_IWUSR, LINUX_S_IXGRP, LINUX_S_IXOTH, LINUX_S_IXUSR.

Returns:
The native-context file handle. You must call fileclose(int) manually.
Throws:
JVRException - on error

wtring

public static int wtring(int dev,
                         int rings,
                         int hookState,
                         int timeout)
                  throws JVRException
Waits for a specified number of rings, then sets the given channel to the given hookstate.

Dialogic API Reference for this function: (win32,linux)

On Linux only: You can terminate a call to wtring by calling stopch(int, int) from another thread. See the Linux Dialogic API docs for dx_wtring for all of the details. Stopping dx_wtring is not supported on Win32 in 5.1.1/SP1. If you need to terminate dx_wtring on win32, use shorter timeout values (say 1 second) and an out-of-band control flag instead.

Parameters:
dev - Handle to device on which to perform action
rings - Number of rings to wait for.
hookState - The hookstate to set to after receiving the rings. DX_ONHOOK or DX_OFFHOOK.
timeout - Time, in seconds, to wait for the rings. Specify -1 to wait forever.
Returns:
Nothing useful, exception on error.
Throws:
JVRException - on error.

recwav

public static int recwav(int dev,
                         java.lang.String filename,
                         DV_TPT[] tpt,
                         DX_XPB xpb,
                         int mode)
                  throws JVRException
Records voice data to a single wav file (Win32 Only).

Dialogic API Reference for dx_recwav: (win32)

Example: 

 // Provide a filename for recording the file.  This can be
 // any valid filename such as "c:\\temp\\myfile.wav" or
 // "\\someother.wav".
 String filename = "foobar.wav";

 // I forget what the transfer parameter block is for, but
 // leaving it as 'null' will still produce valid WAV files.
 DX_XPB xpb = null;

 // Specify one or more termination clauses for the operation.
 DV_TPT tpt[] = DV_TPT.newArray(2);
 // This one means "record for no more than 5 seconds".
 tpt[0].tp_type = dx.IO_CONT;
 tpt[0].tp_termno = dx.DX_MAXTIME;
 tpt[0].tp_length = 50;
 tpt[0].tp_flags = dx.TF_MAXTIME;
 // This one means "stop when you hear 1 key press".
 tpt[1].tp_type = dx.IO_EOT;
 tpt[1].tp_termno = dx.DX_MAXDTMF;
 tpt[1].tp_length = 1;
 tpt[1].tp_flags = dx.TF_MAXDTMF;

 // Record to the wav file.  "RM_TONE" will cause a short
 // tone to be played before recording begins, as in
 // "Leave your message at the beap".  EV_SYNC is mandatory.
 dx.recwav(dxdev, filename, tpt, xpb, dx.RM_TONE|dx.EV_SYNC);
 
 // And just for fun, play the file right back.  Obviously
 // this has nothing to do with recording and is optional.
 //
 // Reset the termination clause to only terminate on a key
 // press.  Since this is a playback operation, it will
 // automatically stop at the end of the file (so we don't
 // need to worry about a MAXTIME clause.
 tpt = DV_TPT.newArray(1);
 tpt[0].tp_type = dx.IO_EOT;
 tpt[0].tp_termno = dx.DX_MAXDTMF;
 tpt[0].tp_length = 1;
 tpt[0].tp_flags = dx.TF_MAXDTMF;
 dx.playwav(dxdev, filename, tpt, dx.EV_SYNC);

Parameters:
dev - Handle to the device on which the action is performed.
filename - Filename of the wav file to record to.
tpt - Array of termination parameters.
xpb - Transfer parameter block.
mode - Bitmask mode. dx.EV_SYNC is mandatory. Include dx.RM_TONE to play audible tone before recording.
Throws:
JVRException - on any error.

wtcallid

public static java.lang.String wtcallid(int dev,
                                        int rings,
                                        int timeout)
                                 throws JVRException
Waits for an incoming call then picks up the line and returns caller id information. Note that you have to enable Caller ID detection on the chanel first using dx.setparm(dev,dx.DXCH_CALLID,dx.DX_CALLIDENABLE)

NOTE: Using my D/41ESC card, I have not managed to get Caller ID information during an incoming call. I suspect it is my card, so you're system may have better luck. If you manage to use this function successfully, please let me know so I can remove this notice.

Dialogic API Reference for dx_wtcallid: (win32,linux)

Parameters:
dev - Handle to the device on which the action is performed.
rings - Number of rings to wait until the call is returned.
timeout - Number of seconds to wait for an incoming call. Specify -1 to wait forever.
Throws:
JVRException - on any error.
